args:
This is a tale of events three hundred years ago,
when a young Alberius is traveling the wide,
wide world with the Windwyrm, Midgardsormr.
One day, after saving a young woman from
Dyrenell Empire soldiers, she gifts him a
mysterious blade and begs him to keep it safe...
Seven hundred years after Ilia and Elysium\nsealed away the Other, Grastaea found itself\nbeset by the unending drumbeat of war.

It was in this turbulent era that the nation of
Dyrenell was born—a nation whose zealous
worship of the Other was so great, they chose
to unleash the sealed fiend once more.
Thus was the world threatened anew\nby the horror of the Other.

But in that moment, a man appeared to face
the calamity that left all others trembling.
A man who bore the dragon's blood handed
down since the ancient pact was formed.
A man by the name of...Alberius.

Through his opposition to the Other's menace,
Alberius became a beacon of hope.
Soon countless peoples of all races
coalesced around him as their leader.

Alberius drew strength from his friendships
with the people, and succeeded in sealing
away the Other once more. Thus was the
Second War of Binding brought to an end.
Soon, the Kingdom of Alberia rose up from the\nruined land with Alberius at its center.
The bards sing of a great hero who\ndefeated evil, brought hope and order to\nthe world, and founded a new kingdom.

Such songs and tales turn Alberius into
an almost superhuman figure—one who
scarce resembles the actual flesh-and-
blood man who once walked the land.
In fact, what I remember most vividly...\nAh, yes. Of course.
This is a tale of the long ago, before I\nunderstood the full swath of the world,\nand when his dreams were yet unrealized.
It was a time when the world's laws\nforged a rift between people and dragons.
That is the great strand of mountains\nthat divides North and South Grastaea!\nTruly it is a sight worth our long journey.
There are countless peaks of considerably\ngreater height all across the world,\nso why do you marvel at these whelps?
Are there now? Well then, I think this calls\nfor a new adventure to see them all!

You are more than free to do so—alone.
I have no intention of following you to the
ends of the earth in this body. Even calling
forth storms is a struggle as I am now.
You can still call storms even in that form,\neh? Well, you probably shouldn't do that\nwhile we're in any towns.
I make no promise to that end.

Dragons do not interfere with people, and I
cause storms to neither help nor hinder;
I simply act when the voice of nature
dictates such to be necessary.
Which means all the people trying to pray\nstorms away are simply wasting their time\nfretting over your capriciousness.
I am merely respecting our boundaries.\nPeople and dragons ought not to interfere\novermuch in one another's affairs.
So you always say. Yet I think the world\nwould be a much wider place if people\nand dragons worked together.

Then what do you propose? Shall I make
the wind sing on your people's command
and bring the rains at their beck and call?
Such actions could easily breed disorder.

We dragons act on nature's behalf so we
might safeguard the order of the world.
Getting too close to people would only
engender needless conflict.
Then the world will never change.\nFor while we have calm, we cannot\nhave progress...
I'm sorry, I'm in a bit of a rush...
We have you, girl! Now be smart and hand\nover the sword, and we might see fit to\nspare your miserable life.
I will never permit the Dyrenell Empire\nto lay hands on this!
Then we will have it by force!

I don't know what's going on here,
but don't you think you're being a tad
rough? I can't just stand by and let you
take what is not yours.
You'll regret sticking your nose in this,\nwhoever you are. ...Men! Seize this\ndo-gooder and put him in the ground!
I thought we'd spend more time in the\ndiplomacy phase of this, but so be it.\nIf it's a fight you want, you shall have it!
You lot clearly have no chance against me.\nBest to slink away while you still can.

You're getting awfully soused at the sound
of your own voice, dog—but we'll teach
you to respect the power of Dyrenell yet!
...O great king, grant me your might!
What the blazes? They summoned a fiend!

Please, save your applause for the encore.
For even if my body may change, I will
not fail to fulfill the charge given me by
His Grace the Emperor!
Now he has transformed INTO a fiend!\nCould this be the power of...?
Can I leave the minions to you?
I suppose we must; these miscreants seem\npoised to upset the balance of the world,\nand I am unable to let that be.
Then I leave the rest in your hands\nwhile I deal with this one!
Such power! I won't be able to withstand\nmuch of that!
Grraah... My duty...is to remove\nanything...that would interfere with\nour master's resurrection...!
You took quite a blow from that beast.\nBest not to move for a while.
Easy, now. I'm not the sort to turn tail\nand leave you to fend for yourself.
I have just one thing to ask of you...
This is the sacred blade Dragalia.\nWould you please see it safely to the\nnearby cathedral of the Ilian Church?
The fate of this world may well hinge\nupon this blade!
You would entrust something so vital\nto a stranger?

It cannot be allowed to fall into enemy
hands—and though I sound like a naive
babe to say it, you seem a trustworthy sort.
Please, I beg of you! Save Dragalia!
I see. Still, if you trust me so, there is yet\none further option available to us.
I take your sword and use it\nto dispatch that fiend.
No, you mustn't! That sword is—
I fear the time for reasoned discussion\nis past. Serve me well, Dragalia!
No, you misunderstand!\nThat sword can't be drawn from its\nscabbard!
My word... This sword didn't just dispatch\nthe beast—it annihilated it utterly!
No sooner had I removed the blade from\nits sheath than it began to glow and struck\ndown the fiend as if of its own will.
I never thought to meet you in such\na place, and yet there can be no doubt...
You're a descendant of\nthe dragon bloodline!
